 Silly girl. You do know the name "Halliburton"? All the accusations flying about Cheney and Halliburton?
 
 "Current criticism over Halliburton's lucrative Iraq contracts has some historians drawing parallels to a similar controversy involving the company during Lyndon B. Johnson's administration.
 
 Nearly 40 years ago, Halliburton faced almost identical charges over its work for the U.S. government in Vietnam -- allegations of overcharging, sweetheart contracts from the White House and war profiteering. Back then, the company's close ties to President Johnson became a liability. Today -- as NPR's John Burnett reports in the last of a three-part series -- Halliburton seems to be distancing itself from its former chief executive officer, Vice President Dick Cheney.
 
 The story of Halliburton's ties to the White House dates back to the 1940s, when a Texas firm called Brown & Root constructed a massive dam project near Austin. The company's founders, Herman and George Brown, won the contract to build Mansfield Dam thanks to the efforts of Johnson, who was then a Texas congressman. Back when FDR opened the door for them.
 
 After Johnson took over the Oval Office, Brown & Root won contracts for huge construction projects for the federal government. By the mid-1960s, newspaper columnists and the Republican minority in Congress began to suggest that the company's good luck was tied to its sizable contributions to Johnson's political campaign.
 
 More questions were raised when a consortium of which Brown & Root was a part won a $380 million contract to build airports, bases, hospitals and other facilities for the U.S. Navy in South Vietnam. By 1967, the General Accounting Office had faulted the "Vietnam builders" -- as they were known -- for massive accounting lapses and allowing thefts of materials.
 
 Brown & Root also became a target for anti-war protesters: they called the firm the embodiment of the "military-industrial complex" and denounced it for building detention cells to hold Viet Cong prisoners in South Vietnam.
 Today, Brown & Root is called Kellogg, Brown & Root -- a Halliburton subsidiary better known as KBR.
 
 Halliburton Deals Recall Vietnam-Era Controversy : NPR
 
 That's just for starters simone. Surely you aren't so naive as to believe a simple, country boy history teacher like LBJ became a mega-millionaire via hard work?

Iuris

As to the price of health insurance:
 It's damn necessary to reform the US system, but I must say it was a bad time to go for it - two wars AND a recession is the time where even the most needed expensive projects have a good chance to fail.
 
 As to the price of war:
 The US, even though the mightiest and richest nation of the world, is neither mighty nor rich enough to actually change the world through war. There are many dictators who richly deserve a bullet, but wars cost simply too much to actually do it.
 
 To the lesser countries have that lesson is obvious - all they have to do is look at their own military might and think about how much more it would take. To the hegemon of the time, however, this is a lesson to be learned.
 
 But it's a lesson to consider BEFORE you start a war you can't finish. Once you've started, how could one DARE to consider bailing out? Leaving the civilians and allies without support to the enemy? All that loss of life and infrastructure (which actually matters, a lot, since it's loss can easily mean the loss of life), all that suffering - all for nothing? How could they even think about such an idea?
 
 Suck it up, or be forever remembered for what you did.
romebigred

No more funding of these stupid wars off the books.
 Start paying for them up front just like we're supposed to do for health care for Americans.
 A surtax on the rich who are benefiting from profiteering on the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
 No surtax? No surge.
 An evilly unfair burden has been put on American's soldiers and their families, the soldiers who have been deployed and redeployed and redeployed and redeployed over and over again while Dick Cheney makes money off both wars.
 

 
 You know, I hear a lot of these kinds of accusations, but I see NO evidence. 
 
 Now, I know two millionaires personally. They worked VERY hard to get there. Their parents didn't have college degrees, and their families were always poor when they were little. They swore they would grow up to do more. They worked their butts off to get into good schools, and worked their butts off to make good business. More than 60 hours a week. They scrimped and saved, and were very smart with their money. One is a consultant. He has 11 kids. He consults in Industrial Psychology. The other started an eye care business.
 
 Why should they be taxed for something that they didn't start?
 
 Also, if you ever want our troops OUT of Afghanistan and Iraq, then we NEED this surge. It's to wipe out the groups that could endanger the new democratic government when we pull out. If we pull out now, this government will fall, and an anti-American government will take their place. History proves this. Look at what happened to Iraq, Iran, Cuba AND Afghanistan the first time. So, in other words, if you want to have to have another war, just doing the same thing over again in 20 years, then it's fine to pull out now.
